COURSE_TITLE: Professional Writing and Communication for Computer Scientists
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Instruction in discipline-specific workplace writing and communication skills for computer science graduate students. Open only to graduate students in Computer Science. Graded CR/NC.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_TITLE: Professional Writing and Communication for Computer Scientists
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Instruction in discipline-specific workplace writing and communication skills for computer science graduate students. Open only to graduate students in Computer Science. Graded CR/NC.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Course content to be selected each semester from recent developments in computer science.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Advanced techniques for analyzing and verifying software systems; topics include program analysis, automated verification, and software testing.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Animation and Simulation techniques for computer games, virtual reality, and film visual effects. Research methods, SIGGRAPH papers. Deformable objects, fluids, sound, collision detection, haptics, rigid bodies, GPUs. Prerequisite: CSCI 420 or CSCI 520 or CSCI 580. Recommended preparation: Familiari ty with calculus, linear algebra, and numerical computation and C++ programming skills. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Digital geometry processing (subfield of computer graphics), that covers the full pipeline from 3D scanning, processing, to 3D printing. Recommended preparation: Solid background in linear algebra, numerical optimization, and C/C++ programming. CSCI 420 Computer Graphics is recommended. Open only toComputer Science doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_TITLE: Privacy in the World of Big Data
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Privacy challenges that arise in the world driven by data. An overview of algorithmic and technical approaches to addressing them.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Computational models of natural language dialogue; conversational interfaces to artificial systems; dialogue system architectures and applications; Reinforcement learning of dialogue policies.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Focus on foundations and techniques for information integration. Topics include Semantic Web, linked data, data integration, entity linkage, source modeling, and information extraction. Prerequisite: CSCI 561. Recommended preparation: CSCI 585 and programming experience. Open only to Computer Scienc e doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Computer communication protocols and systems, including classic and contemporary literature. The emphasis is on conceptual issues in the design and implementation of computer internetworks.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Fundamental techniques for design and analysis of algorithms. Dynamic programming; network flows; theory of NP-completeness; linear programming; approximation, randomized, and online algorithms; basic cryptography. Prerequisite: CSCI 570. Recommended preparation: familiarity with algorithms and disc rete mathematics. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Algorithmic techniques include combinatorial algorithms and rounding of linear and semi-definite programs. Applications include network design, graph cuts, covering problems, and approximation hardness.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Algorithmic techniques include combinatorial algorithms and rounding of linear and semi-definite programs. Applications include network design, graph cuts, covering problems, and approximation hardness.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Topics include: Convex sets and functions; convex optimization problems; geometric and Lagrangian duality; simplex algorithm; ellipsoid algorithm and its implications; matroid theory; submodular optimization.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Advanced techniques in database management. Topics include optimization, cache management, data mining and knowledge discovery, decision support, spatial indexes, parallel and distributed systems, extendible storage. Prerequisite: CSCI 485 or CSCI 585.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction of Ph.D. students to the broad range of computer science research. Two semesters registration required. Open to Computer Science doctoral students only. Graded CR/NC. Duplicates credit in former CSCI 597.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Practical principles for the long-term development of effective teaching in Computer Science. Intended for teaching assistants for classes offered by the Computer Science department. Graded CR/NC. Open only to Computer Science doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Andrew and Erna Viterbi School of Engineering

COURSE_TITLE: International Political Economy of the Pacific Rim
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Political economy of the Pacific Rim; trade, investment and development strategies. The role of Japan's increasing economic power and that of the changing U.S.Japan relations and their implications to the rest of the Pacific Rim region. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permi ssion to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: Democracy and Democratization in Comparative Perspective
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Seminar generates and tests theories of democratization. Readings will focus on Europe, Latin America, Soviet Eurasia emphasizing core theoretical and methodological aspects. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to experimental techniques and applications of experiments in political science. Addresses both the advantages and disadvantages of experiments in political science research. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Maximum likelihood estimation of binary choice models, duration models, count models, and other models in political science, international relations, and social sciences. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Theoretical and methodological problems in American politics with emphasis on emerging research paradigms. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: American Politics Field Seminar Part II
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: A theoretical and empirical overview of the American politics field. Theoretical topics include behavioralism, rational choice, political psychology; empirical topics include causality. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Determinants, nature, and consequences of political attitudes and behavior exploring psychological-sociological models, political socialization and learning, and factors affecting trends in attitudes and behavior. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for t he course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Theory and empirical analysis as it relates to the study of political institutions. Legislative politics, executive branch politics, and legislative-executive relations and bargaining. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Governmental process in the People's Republic of China including leadership, ideology, political institutions, behavior, and participation. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Survey of literature; examination of approaches, concepts, and issues in the field of comparative politics. Duplicates credit in former POSC 520. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Seminar covering literature and methods in the study of political economy, authoritarianism, redistribution, and political conflict. Builds directly on POIR 640.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: Institutions in Comparative and International Politics
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Explores major strands of institutional theory and assesses scholars views on design of institutions, institutional change, and effects of institutions on behavior and outcomes. Open only to doctoral students in POIR.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: International Human Rights Law and Policy
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Historical and contemporary consideration of human rights issues in world politics. Examination of philosophical foundations of human rights and institutions that enforce international standards. MA and other students outside of POIR must obtain faculty permission to register for the course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_TITLE: Comparative Politics of East and Southeast Asia
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Comparison of significant political phenomena between the countries in the East and Southeast Asia region and the long-term consequences of such comparisons. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Rules and rule structures in international relations; major theoretical perspectives and empirical research. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Survey of approaches to international political economy. Intellectual roots; the management of collective goods; North-South relations are examined. Open only to doctoral students.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Dana and David Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Examination of the interconnected fields of international security and foreign policy, including decision making and patterns of interaction regarding international conflict. Open only to doctoral students.

DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Evolution of mathematical ideas and techniques as seen through astudy of the contributions of eminent mathematicians to the formulation and solution of celebrated problems.Recommended preparation: upper division MATH course.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Formulation and study of models arising in population dynamics, growth of plankton, pollution of rivers, highway traffic, morphogenesis and tidal dynamics: stability, oscillations, bifurcations, chaos. The lab will consist of computer simulation of models using commercially available software.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Formulation and study of models arising in population dynamics, growth of plankton, pollution of rivers, highway traffic, morphogenesis and tidal dynamics: stability, oscillations, bifurcations, chaos. The lab will consist of computer simulation of models using commercially available software.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Polynomial rings, vector spaces, linear transformations,canonical forms, inner product spaces.Recommended preparation: MATH 410.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Lectures on advanced material not covered in regularly scheduled courses. No more than two registrations allowed. Prerequisite: Departmental Approval.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Lectures directed to mathematics graduate students by faculty of the department and by outside speakers.Problem solving workshops.Graded CR/NC.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Linear equations and matrices, Gauss elimination, error estimates, iteration techniques; contractive mappings, Newton's method; matrix eigenvalue problems; least-squares approximation, Newton-Cotes and Gaussian quadratures; finite difference methods. Prerequisite: linear algebra and calculus.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Computational linear algebra; solution of general nonlinear systems of equations; approximation theory using functional analysis; numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Markov processes in discrete or continuous time; renewal processes; martingales; brownian motion and diffusion theory; random walks, inventory models, population growth, queuing models, shot noise.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: B: Commutative Algebra: Integrality, Hilbert Basis theorem, Hilbert Nullstellensatz; Modules: modules over PID's, chain conditions, tensor products; Noncommutative Rings: Jacobson radical, Artin-Wedderburn theorem, Maschke's theorem.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Theory of analytic functions--power series and integral representations, calculus of residues, harmonic functions, normal families, approximation theorems, conformal mapping, analytical continuation.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: a: Measure and integration over abstract measure spaces, Radon-Nikodym theorem, Fubini's theorem, convergence theorems, differentiation. Prerequisite: 425ab. b: Metric spaces, contraction principle, category, Banach spaces, Riesz representation theorem, properties of Lp, Hilbert spaces, orthogonalexpansions, Fourier series and transforms, convolutions. Prerequisite: 525a.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Advanced topics in stochastic analysis, asset pricing in continuous time, stochastic control, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations, incomplete markets, American options, exotic options, term structure of interest rates. Duplicates credit in the former MATH-506.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Elementary theory of manifolds, Lie groups, homogeneous spaces, fiber bundles and connections. Riemannian manifolds, curvature and conjugate points, second fundamental form, other topics. Prerequisite: 440.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Parametric families of distributions, sufficiency.Estimation:methods of moments, maximum likelihood, unbiased estimation. Comparison of estimators, optimality, information inequality, asymptotic efficiency.EM algorithm, jacknife and bootstrap.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Second-order partial differential equations of elliptic,parabolic, and hyperbolic type; in particular, potential and wave equations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Existence, uniqueness and continuation of solutions, differential inequalities, linear systems, Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems, Poincare-Bendixson theory, periodic solutions, perturbations, stability, fixed point techniques.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Applications of the mathematical, statistical and computationalsciences to data from molecular biology. Algorithms for genomic sequence data: sequence and map assembly and alignment, RNA secondary structure, protein structure, gene-finding, and tree construction.Recommended preparation: familiarity with the concepts of basic molecular biology as covered in BISC 320.
DEPTOWNERNAME: LAS - Natural Sciences & Mathematics

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to and discussion on clinically relevant topics such as social determinants of health, medical ethics and legal and regulatory aspects, in preparation for experience in the clinical setting.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Introduction to Professionalism and the Practice of Medicine
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An introduction to professionalism and skills required in the practice of medicine and careers in health care.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Challenges in the Forefront of Biomedical Ethics
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Examination of fundamental ethical concepts and principles in clinical health care and biomedical research. Use of film, case studies and discussion. Recommended Preparation: MDA-110 or MEDS-220.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: The History of Medicine: a Doctor's Perspective
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Explores the role of medicine/surgery in society, whose ideas about health and disease have undergone enormous changes from antiquity to the present day.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Human Anatomy, Physiology, and the Technology of Medicine
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to human anatomy and physiology in relation to common disease processes, and an examination of how technology has transformed western medicine throughout history.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Anatomical structure and function of the major regions of the human body as related to health and disease, using clinical cases, lectures and cadaveric demonstrations.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: The Brain in Health and Disease
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Study of the human brain through the lens of disease using illustrative case studies, current imaging techniques and potential future treatment for neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Neurochemistry of Addiction: Drugs, Brain, and Behavior
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: The neurochemistry of psychiatric illness and addiction, introduction to brain and nervous system biochemistry, anatomy and disease states. Covers prescribed medications and drugs of abuse.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Skeletal Biology and Pathology: No Bones About It
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Overview of the cellular make-up of the human skeleton, the functions of bones, clinical application of this knowledge towards bone-related diseases, and introduction to technological advances in orthopedic surgery.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An examination of frequently treated diseases with the greatest impact on society. Involvement of medical specialists as guests.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploring how stem cells and regenerative medicine are portrayed in culture, the scientific underpinnings of what is currently possible, and visions into the future. Prerequisites: BISC 220L or BISC 221L.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Health Care Systems: A Doctor's Perspective
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An examination of the health care system of the United States, from the perspective of the physician and other health professions. Particularly covers health care systems as a workplace and how medical professionals fit into and operate within it.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Emphasizes the team-based approach used by forensic scientists, medical examiners and coroners to investigate the circumstances and determine the cause/manner of death. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Open only to sophomores, juniors, and seniors.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Introduction to the spectrum of surgical care, taught by surgeons, with the goal of developing an appreciation of the role that surgery plays in society. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and CHEM 103 or CHEM 105a or CHEM 115a and MEDS 220. Open only to juniors and seniors.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: OB/GYN: The Medicine and Surgery of Reproduction
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: An introduction to the practical realities of modern obstetric and gynecology practice from the point of view of practicing surgeon scientists at USC. Prerequisites: BISC-220 or BISC-221 and MEDS-220.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Principles of emergency medical services, ranging from pre-hospital care and advanced life-saving, to minor injuries and illnesses. Interactive experience with ER physicians/emergency health care providers. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220. Recommended preparation: MEDS 260.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Medical physiology principles of people under "extreme" wilderness conditions, factors affecting remote medical care, and basic survival strategies, led by Emergency Medicine physicians. Prerequisites: BISC 220 or BISC 221 and MEDS 220.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploration of biological and epidemiological fundamentals of tuberculosis including dynamics of transmission among populations. Overview of clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and treatment of infections.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Global Health Modules, Maternal and Child Health
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Biopsychosocial, cultural and economic aspects of womens health: pregnancy, childbirth, marriage. Examination of health promotion and policy efforts to improve womens health globally.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Children in Emergency Situations: Global Policies and Programs
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Focuses on children in emergency situations, including natural and man-made disasters, such as floods, earthquakes, conflicts, or war, with an emphasis on the poorest and most vulnerable children. Open only to Global Medicine majors.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_TITLE: Medical Spanish for the Health Professions
COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Spanish language course for students planning to enter the health professions. Graded CR/NC.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Exploration of the threat of major worldwide epidemics and diseases with a focus on the recent emergence of new plagues.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: The basics of human anatomy (gross anatomy, histology, radiographic anatomy), physiology (cellular physiology, organ system areas) and pathology (general, systemic, cellular pathology).
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

COURSE_DESCRIPTION: Two-week course providing students with a solid understanding of the United Nations major agencies influential in global health, their mandate, their strengths and challenges. Includes field visit to selected UN organizations all located in NYC. Open only to Global Medicine majors.
DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine

DEPTOWNERNAME: Keck School of Medicine
